awd_titl_txt: Role of Silicon and Light in Regulating Diatom Cell Cycles
awd_abstract_narration: Diatoms are microscopic, single celled plants that are                     responsible for much of the biological productivity in the ocean.               Their absolute requirement for silica makes them unique among the               phytoplankton and the interaction of light and silica in                        regulating the cell division (or growth) of these plants will be                addressed in this research.  Dr. Olson will collaborate with Dr.                Chisholm from M.I.T. and a post doctoral researcher to examine                  several questions regarding the exact nature and number of block                points in the diatom cell division cycle that are controlled by                 light and silica availability.  The specific strategies for                     dealing with these limitations will be studied using cell                       cytometry in a highly integrated cell biological approach to                    marine biology.
